Republican State Senator Doug Mastriano, who voted for Act 77 in 2019, introduced a bill in November 2021 to repeal certain provisions of the law, including eliminating no-excuse mail voting.
Some conservatives in the state turned against the law after President Joe Biden won Pennsylvania, claiming the expanded access to mail ballots cost former President Donald Trump the state.
In its decision, the court noted that the law has expanded access to the ballot, but the majority said that any changes to mail voting laws would require a constitutional amendment.
In a statement, the Pennsylvania Department of State said it "disagrees with today's ruling and is working to file an immediate appeal to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court."
"I do not believe that mail in voting is unconstitutional, and there were not constitutional concerns brought up when the bill passed nearly unanimously in '19."
A Pennsylvania court on Friday struck down Act 77, the law that established no-excuse mail voting in Pennsylvania, saying it violated the state Constitution.
The Pennsylvania Commonwealth Court said the state's constitution requires votes to be cast in-person unless voters meet certain requirements.
Republicans have blasted previous court decisions about the law and criticized the Pennsylvania executive branch's implementation of the law.
Pennsylvania Senate minority leader Jay Costa, a Democrat, said he is hopeful that the Pennsylvania Supreme Court will reverse the decision.
Fourteen Republicans in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives sued last year, arguing that the law was unconstitutional.
In 2020, the first general election in which the law was in effect, 2.6 million Pennsylvanians voted by mail.
The court's three Republicans ruled that the law was unconstitutional, while the two Democrats dissented.
